abstracts.cdata!:
Based on the output indicators and most
            of the outcome indicators, the project is rated
            satisfactory. The project was implemented in a very
            difficult period in Rwanda and made an important
            contribution to helping the country in its transition from
            war to peace. Given the private business investments
            financed under the line of credit component, the
            institutional improvements implemented at the central bank
            and the institutional and legal reform process started,
            sustainability of the project is likely. Both World Bank and
            Borrower performances were rated satisfactory: The Bank
            maintained the dialogue with the Borrower during the
            difficult period after the war and helped significantly in
            ensuring effectiveness of the project; and while there were
            significant delays in all components of the project, the
            Borrower carried out a large scope of activities in a
            satisfactory way. These were some of the lessons learned:
            Separate legal and regulatory reforms from technical
            assistance. In the aftermath of a civil war, projects have
            to be adjusted to the new circumstances and be focused on
            priorities. A constituency for reform is crucial for
            implementation. Capable implementing agencies are critical
            for implementation. Instruments need to fit country
            circumstances. Structural deficiencies in the financial
            sector have to be addressed to guarantee long-term viability
            of the sector.

18156077.trustfund: TF028001-FAC CONSULTANT TRUST FUND,TF021344-PRIVATE SECTOR DEVELOPMENT
18156077.majtheme: Trade and integration,Financial and private sector development,Economic management,Rule of law

abstracts.cdata!:
Rwanda's inflation rate was low and
            its growth rate sustained from 1970 to the mid 1980s. GDP
            has declined since then due to low coffee prices and poor
            weather. The objective of this project is to promote swift
            growth of the Rwandan private sector. The private sector is
            considered a key element in a strategy for growth and
            diversification. The project will promote efforts to ensure
            that the private sector has access to investment financing
            and managerial and technical support. It will also support
            efforts to improve the legal and regulatory environment and
            enhance the investment and export incentives. The three
            components of the project which will aid in achieving these
            goals include: line of credit; private sector support fund;
            and institutional strengthening. The Rwandan government
            believes that growth led by the private sector can provide
            employment and make a significant contribution to export
            earnings. The project is a complement to Rwanda's
            macroeconomic adjustment program already in place.
